Japanese

Degree

BA in World Languages and Linguistics

School

Humanities and Social Sciences

Department

World Languages and Cultures

At a Glance

Study global languages, cultures, and literature to better understand our multicultural world and open doors to diverse career opportunities. Mastery of a language like Japanese is a highly valued skill that applies to nearly any industry. The Japanese specialization within the world languages and linguistics major provides a strong foundation in linguistics and language acquisition along with in-depth Japanese language study. Youâ€™ll graduate with a liberal arts education and gain immersive cultural experiences, including study abroad, that will prepare you for a global career.

Youâ€™ll Benefit From:

  • An innovative program in world languages and linguistics thatâ€™s unique to TCNJ
  • Small class sizes, individual attention, and extensive use of the target language
  • Immersive cultural experiences like trips, speakers, festivals, and performances
  • A weekly oral-proficiency hour for small-group practice in a relaxed atmosphere
  • Participation in community-engaged activities assisting non-English speakers
  • First-rate instruction and strong mentorship from expert faculty
  • Study abroad opportunities available at more than 100 locations
  • A flexible curriculum that easily accommodates double majors or additional minors

Careers

Youâ€™ll graduate with the skills, insights, and experiences that appeal to both top employers and graduate schools. Knowledge of other languages and cultures can significantly enhance your career opportunities in any field, including business, education, law, medicine, healthcare, international education, nonprofit, government, technology, marketing, social services, and more. You will also be well-prepared to pursue graduate school at top institutions.

Course Sequence

The major assumes no previous foreign-language study. Even if you enter with no knowledge of a foreign language, you will have ample time to complete the required seven language courses and five linguistics courses. If you enter the program at a higher proficiency level, you can take a more significant number of upper-level courses in the foreign language. You will be actively encouraged to complete at least one study abroad semester and can take three language and linguistics courses for the major and one free elective during your semester abroad.
